content: You make an interesting point with the VHS vs. BetaMax comparison. VHS won out because it provided a very important feature that BetaMax did not — the ability to record (or play back) a full-length movie on one tape. The moral of the story is that a product succeeds not by being technologically superior, but by simply meeting the demands of the market. If we were living in the early 80s, and you and I were having a BetaMax vs. VHS discussion, I would tell you that focusing on one technological feature (picture quality) is short-sighted, and that you need to take the larger forces of the market into account. A product that offers nothing more than great underlying technology will fail. Incidentally, I think many of your assumptions regarding Ethereum are questionable or outright incorrect. It’s easy to lull yourself into a false sense of security when everyone around you is telling you not to worry about it, and that you are right. (IE, the majority of responses to your article.) Remember that most of the people agreeing with you here have an economic incentive to do so. Incidentally, I’d say you might want to re-visit your ideas about PoS — the concept has come a long way, and may actually be viable. I’ve been following the evolution of ideas, and what I’d say in summary, is that a lot of really smart people are coming up with some very elegant solutions to the perceived problems. I think it’s only a matter of time until this is solved. Additionally, Raiden had a recently successful proof-of-concept demo.
